thread.title: Fraternal Order of Eagles donates more than $50,000 to Geauga County first responders, veterans
thread.title_full: Fraternal Order of Eagles donates more than $50,000 to Geauga County first responders, veterans

author: William Tilton, The News-Herald, Willoughby, Ohio
title: Fraternal Order of Eagles donates more than $50,000 to Geauga County first responders, veterans
text:
The News-Herald, Willoughby, Ohio Fraternal Order of Eagles donates more than $50,000 to Geauga County first responders, veterans William Tilton, The News-Herald, Willoughby, Ohio Updated Thu, December 26, 2024 at 10:02 PM UTC 1 min read
The holiday season of giving started early in Geauga County thanks to the Fraternal Order of Eagles, Geauga Aerie 2261, and many first responders and veterans were the direct beneficiaries.
The donations will also have an impact on the entire community.
On Nov. 15, in keeping with its motto “People Helping People,” the Aerie continued the tradition of “Giving with Gratitude” when it presented checks of $5,000 each to nine fire departments in Geauga County.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement The departments in Burton Township, Chardon Township, Chester Township, Hambden Township, Newbury Township, Middlefield Township, Munson Township, Montville Township and Thompson Township each received donations.
In addition, a $5,000 check was presented to the Chardon Police Department for their “Shop With A Cop” Program, which provides Christmas gifts for needy children in the community.
“This is a great opportunity for us to give back to the community and show our appreciation to our first responders,” said Kurt Feigle, president of Aerie 2261.
Another donation was made to the Geauga County Veterans Food Pantry of $1,000 along with a special donation from Consumer Tire Angel Wings of $6,563, which was presented by Bruce Kantz, David Kantz and DD Coley.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Consumer was recently sold and Coley stated they started the charity to help veterans and seniors with car repairs, but decided to donate the remainder of the funds to help feed veterans.
Mark Coley, secretary for the Aerie, said “this is the best part of the officer’s job, supporting first responders, children and veterans.”
Many of the FOE officers sharing in Coley’s sentiment presented the checks to the selected organizations. The combination of all donations was $57,563.
